references: In this section, we survey the advanced FL algorithms in the CV community, aiming to alleviate the effects of training data heterogeneity across clients during FL training. We categorize the existing algorithms into two groups: 1) local training focused algorithms [10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15]; and 2) model aggregation focused algorithms [16, 17, 8, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24] based on their advanced local training and aggregation strategies during FL that is summarized in Table I.

S3.T2.caption: TABLE II: The Theoretical Comparison of the Selected FL Algorithms. Three Marks ”H” (High), ”M” (Medium), or “L” (Low) Are Given for the Considered Criteria.

Algorithm Local Training Complexity Aggregation Complexity Learning Efficiency Communication Cost Scalability

Local Training Focused FedProx [10] M L M L H
SCAFFOLD [11] M L H H M
MOON [12] H L H L H
FedDC [14] M L M H H
Model Aggregation Focused FedNova [16] L M L L L
pFedLA [20] L H L L L
FedBN [8] L M L L L
references: In this section, the selected FL algorithms are theoretically compared based on their: i) local training complexity; ii) aggregation complexity; iii) learning efficiency; iv) communication cost; and v) scalability in terms of number of clients. The comparison of the algorithms under each criterion is given in a separate subsection below, while their overall comparison is summarized in Table II.

S5.T3.caption: TABLE III: Decentralization Scenarios Designed for the BigEarthNet-S2 Benchmark Archive
S5.T3.table:
Scenario Acquisition Conditions of Each Client Training Data Heterogeneity
DS1 Summer season on all countries Low
DS2 Summer season on a specific country Medium
DS3 All seasons on a specific country High
references: Due to the design of decentralization scenarios, each scenario is associated with a different level of training data heterogeneity across clients. The lowest level of heterogeneity is present in DS1, because the images in the same season are randomly distributed to clients. The highest level of heterogeneity is present in DS3, because the training data is decentralized based on the countries, while each client can include images acquired on the same area in different seasons. All the scenarios are summarized in Table III.

references: In the second set of trials, we assessed the effectiveness of the FL algorithms in terms of the number K𝐾K of clients. Table IV shows the F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores of FL algorithms when different numbers K𝐾K of clients are considered under all the scenarios. One can observe from the table that as K𝐾K increases, most of the algorithms lead to slightly lower F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores. This is due to the increase in the variation of the local model parameters when K𝐾K increases. The effect of the number of clients on the performances of the algorithms is more evident when the number of clients is increased to 282828 from 141414 (i.e., K=14→K=28𝐾14→𝐾28K=14\rightarrow K=28). As an example, under DS1, the F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score of the FedNova algorithm decreases 0.2%percent0.20.2\% when K=7→K=14𝐾7→𝐾14K=7\rightarrow K=14, while it decreases 1%percent11\% when K=14→K=28𝐾14→𝐾28K=14\rightarrow K=28. This is due to the fact that the variation among the local models increases more than the increase in the number of clients. In greater details, when the training data heterogeneity across clients increases (i.e., DS1→→\rightarrowDS3), the ability of the algorithms to overcome the higher number of clients (i.e., scalability) generally decreases. As an example, when K=7→K=28𝐾7→𝐾28K=7\rightarrow K=28, the F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score of the MOON algorithm decreases 1.6%percent1.61.6\% and 4.2%percent4.24.2\% under DS1 and DS2, respectively. This is due to fact that as the number of clients increases when training data is distributed across more heterogeneous clients, the variation among the local models further increases. When the FL algorithms are compared among each other in terms of their scalability towards the number of clients, the decrease on F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores obtained by the local training focused algorithms are generally lower than the other algorithms. However, the ability of these algorithms towards K𝐾K is highly affected by the training data heterogeneity across clients, as it can be seen from the table. This is inline with our theoretical analysis in the Section IV-E. We would like to note that for the rest of experiments, we set the number K𝐾K of clients as K=7𝐾7K=7 for the sake of simplicity.

S6.T5.caption: TABLE V: F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} Scores (%) Obtained by the FL Algorithms Under Decentralization Scenarios
S6.T5.table:
Algorithm DS1 DS2 DS3
FedAvg [5] 79.2 52.2 47.5
Local Training Focused FedProx [10] 79.5 56.3 53.3
SCAFFOLD [11] 78.6 57.2 54.4
MOON [12] 81.7 59.5 55.2
FedDC [14] 78.8 58.4 57.4
Model Aggregation Focused FedNova [16] 80.6 53.7 48.6
pFedLA [20] 81.3 56.8 53.6
FedBN [8] 78.4 62.3 57.1
references: In the first set of trials, we compared the effectiveness of the selected FL algorithms in the context of MLC of RS images. Table V shows the corresponding F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores under decentralization scenarios 1 (DS1), 2 (DS2) and 3 (DS3). One can assess from the table that as training data heterogeneity across clients increases through our decentralization scenarios, each algorithm leads to lower F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores. As an example, the FedNova algorithm achieves more than 25%percent2525\% and 30%percent3030\% higher scores under DS1 compared to those under DS2 and DS3, respectively. In greater details, under DS1, the F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores obtained by the algorithms are close to each other. This is due to the low training data heterogeneity level in DS1, for which the considered FL algorithms do not significantly increase the MLC performance. The algorithms that add proximal terms to the local objective function (i.e., FedProx and MOON) achieve slightly higher results than those obtained by the algorithms based on gradient adjustment techniques (i.e., SCAFFOLD and FedDC) under DS1. As an example, the FedProx algorithm outperforms the FedDC algorithm by 0.4% higher F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score under DS1. In particular, the highest F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score was obtained by the MOON algorithm, which is 3.3%percent3.33.3\% higher than that obtained by the worst performing algorithm (i.e., FedBN) under DS1. This indicates that the elimination of batch normalization parameters from model parameter aggregation at the central server decreases MLC performance when the level of data heterogeneity is not significantly high. However, as the training data heterogeneity increases, the differences in F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} scores obtained by the algorithms significantly increases. As the worst performing algorithm under DS1, the FedBN algorithm achieves the highest F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score under DS2. This shows that FedBN provides more accurate MLC results compared the other algorithms when the concept shift is high. We would like to note that the FedAvg algorithm leads to the lowest scores under both DS2 and DS3 as its learning process is highly interfered by non-IID training data. While comparing the algorithms under DS3, the FedDC algorithm achieves the highest F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} score of 57.4%percent57.457.4\%, which is only 1%percent11\% lower than its performance under DS2. This indicates that the FedDC algorithm is more robust to training data heterogeneity across clients than the other algorithms.

S6.T6.caption: TABLE VI: Computation Times (in seconds) Required by the FL Algorithms to Complete One Communication Round of Local Training
S6.T6.table:
Algorithm              Computation Time       (Local Training)
      FedAvg [5]       184
             Local       Training       Focused       FedProx [10]       189
      SCAFFOLD [11]       199
      MOON [12]       258
      FedDC [14]       199
             Model       Aggregation       Focused       FedNova [16]       184
      pFedLA [20]
      FedBN [8]
references: In the second set of trials, we compared the effectiveness of the considered FL algorithms in terms of their local training complexity. Table VI shows the computation times (in seconds) required by all the algorithms to complete one communication round of local training. As one can observe from the table that the computation time required by the FedAvg, FedNova, FedBN and pFedLA algorithms is the same and equal to 184184184 seconds, which is lower than those required by other algorithms. This is due to the fact that FedNova, FedBN and pFedLA are model aggregation focused algorithms and apply the same local training strategy with the FedAvg algorithm. The computation time required by the FedProx algorithm is 189189189 seconds, which is slightly higher than those required by the model aggregation focused algorithms. This is due to calculating the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance between global and local models in FedProx. The computation time required by the SCAFFOLD and FedDC algorithms is slightly increased compared to that by the FedProx algorithm due to the calculation of the control variate parameters. Since the MOON algorithm extracts the feature vectors of an RS image using three different models, its local training complexity is the highest among other algorithms with the computation time of 258258258 seconds.
